Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
Migratory connectivity for full-cycle conservation of imperiled songbirds

Connecting geographically distinct areas used by migrant songbirds is a formidable challenge. However, migratory connectivity is a research frontier that is essential for understanding population dynamics, informing global conservation plans, and building a framework within which ecological questions about speciation, energetics, disease transmission, and much more can be addressed. It is particularly important to identify population-specific wintering grounds for species experiencing dramatic declines despite apparently high productivity on breeding grounds. In collaboration with researchers from many universities and government agencies, two fast-developing research tools (stable isotope analysis and light-level geolocation) will be employed to identify migration routes and wintering grounds for golden-winged warblers (Vermivora chrysoptera) from ten populations across the species' breeding range. This research will allow investigation of associations between wintering-ground anthropogenic land-use patterns and breeding population trends, and to develop a global conservation plan for this species of high conservation concern. This study will provide a blueprint for investigating range-wide migratory connectivity and initiating global conservation efforts for other migrant songbirds, many of which of are experiencing similar long-term declines.

The Fellow will continue to work with Native American communities in Minnesota by developing a curriculum for schools and summer academies to nurture ecological and environmental interest in underserved Native American youth. The Fellow will also conduct individual educational programs for Native American elementary schools near the study sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Migration ecology and migratory connectivity are research frontiers that are starting to be explored in small songbirds thanks to the miniaturization of tracking technologies like light-level geolocators. Connecting breeding and non-breeding locations and identifying migration routes and important stopover locations for migratory birds is essential for informing full-annual cycle models and global conservation and management plans. This project was designed to address migration ecology and migratory connectivity unknowns for golden-winged warblers (Vermivora chrysoptera), a very small migratory songbird of high conservation concern due to dramatic population declines in some portions of its breeding distribution. The project was slowed by a couple of years due to an abundance of caution as we attempted to harness light-level geolocators to songbirds considerably smaller than any previously marked. In response to doubtful leaders in the field and our own conservative approach to animal welfare, we conducted multiple pilot seasons marking only 40 warblers each year. Those pilot seasons were remarkably successful and we published peer-reviewed articles describing our marking methods and the lack of discernible effects on migration ecology so that other scientists could immediately benefit from this advancement in the field. In addition, this pilot work occurred in the right place at the right time to allow us to describe a unique migration event in another peer-reviewed paper.

 

With multiple years of cautious proof-of-concept work we demonstrated that, with proper methods, songbirds of almost any size can now be marked with light-level geolocators. Following that success, we were able to expand the broader project to mark more golden-winged warblers than originally planned and to add the closely related blue-winged warbler (Vermivora cyanoptera) and phenotypic hybrid birds between the two species, and sample >400 individuals across the breeding range of this intriguing hybridizing species complex. The large-scale sampling and geolocator deployment occurred in 2015 at 22 sites from North Carolina north to Ontario and west to Minnesota and Manitoba. We and our collaborators will return to those sites in 2016, recover geolocators from returning birds, collect additional tissue samples and other data, and continue with light-level analysis and laboratory analysis. Preliminary migratory ecology results from the pilot years are included in a manuscript currently in review with a peer-reviewed journal. This project brought together >20 collaborators from >10 universities, state, provincial, and federal government agencies from the U.S. and Canada, and has now expanded through at least 2017 with additional sampling and analysis.

 

The broader impacts portion of this project took place near some of the Minnesota study sites at the White Earth Indian Reservation. Dr. Streby participated each year in curriculum development and teaching at the White Earth Academy of Math and Science which is a multi-week program held each summer to help Native American students stay excited about science during the summer break. Dr. Streby involved students in participatory lessons on animal migration, bird research methods, animal behavior, climate change, and global conservation issues. Dr. Streby and his lab are excited to continue annual participation in the White Earth Academy of Math and Science well beyond completion of this project.
